awd_titl_txt: Development, Validation, and Application of Multicomponent Atmospheric New Particle Formation Schemes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on investigating the nucleation or formation of very small new particles in the atmosphere. The method relies on complex calculations involving the structural and thermochemical properties of atmospheric clusters.  Modeling results will be compared with measurements where they are available.  The project will result in nucleation schemes that can be incorporated into regional and global models to reduce uncertainties in the assessment of the climatic and environmental impacts of atmospheric aerosols. 

The objective of this effort is to develop new schemes of multicomponent nucleation in the atmosphere involving sulfuric acid, water, ammonia, methylamines, and organics. The project consists of 4 tasks: (1) Quantum chemistry studies of neutral and charged ternary clusters; (2) Development of new nucleation models; (3) Application and evaluation of new nucleation schemes in the atmosphere; and (4) Assessing the climate implications of ternary nucleation processes.  The implications of the new nucleation schemes on the aerosol indirect radiative forcing will be evaluated using the GEOS-Chem model.

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of this project was to develop, validate, and apply multicomponent nucleation schemes to study atmospheric nucleation processes and associated climate impacts.

Intellectual merit: We have developed a kinetically-based H2SO4-H2O-NH3 ternary ion-mediated nucleation (TIMN) model that agrees well the Cosmics Leaving OUtdoor Droplets (CLOUD) measurements (Yu et al., 2018a). NH3 was found to reduce nucleation barriers for neutral, positively charged, and negatively charged clusters differently, and to play an important in new particle formation (NPF) in the lower troposphere. We show that [NH3] has been increasing over the U.S. in the last decade due to the decreasing SO2 and NOx emissions (Yu et al., 2018b). We have also employed H2SO4-Organics clustering thermodynamics from quantum-chemical studies to develop a scheme to incorporate temperature dependence into H2SO4-Organics nucleation parameterization (Yu et al., 2017). We have also studied the roles of nitric acid in sulfuric acid-dimethylamine nucleation (Liu et al., 2021).

We show that, even during wintertime, regional nucleation occurs and contributes significantly to ultrafine-particle and CCN number concentrations over the Northeastern United States (NEUS) (Yu et al., 2020a).  We integrate a size-resolved Advanced Particle Microphysics (APM) module with a photochemical box model and employ the resulting model to understand the microphysical and chemical characteristics of ship plumes (Mao et al., 2021). We use in-situ aircraft measurements of vertical profiles of aerosol size distributions to present a global-scale dataset of NPF occurrence. Together with the result of chemical-transport models, our findings indicate that NPF persists at all longitudes as a global-scale band in the tropical upper troposphere. Our findings suggest that the production of CCN as these new particles descend towards the surface is currently not adequately captured in global models, with potential implications for cloud albedo and the global radiative balance. (Williamson et al., 2019)

We develop a machine learning/artificial intelligence model that quantifies CCN from variables of aerosol composition, atmospheric trace gases, and meteorology (Nair and Yu, 2020). Comprehensive multi-campaign airborne measurements, covering varied physicochemical regimes in the troposphere, confirm the validity of and help probe the inner workings of this machine learning model: revealing for the first time that different ranges of atmospheric aerosol composition and mass correspond to distinct aerosol number size distributions (Nair et al., 2021).

Detailed in situ measurements have been employed to investigate the impacts of aerosol on continental stratocumulus and cumulus, respectively. We find that with increasing cloud condensation nuclei, cloud droplet number concentration (Nd) increases for stratocumulus, but exhibits a negligible change for cumulus (Jia et al., 2019). Satellite-based estimates of radiative forcing by aerosol–cloud interactions are consistently smaller than those from global models, hampering accurate projections of future climate change. We show that the discrepancy can be substantially reduced by correcting sampling biases induced by inherent limitations of satellite measurements, which tend to artificially discard the clouds with high cloud fraction (Jia et al., 2021).

Broader impacts: The grant has supported the professional development and training of Ph.D. students, undergraduate students, research technician, and junior research scientist. The research findings gained under this project have been conveyed to all UAlbany graduate students entering the Department of Atmospheric and Environmental Sciences each year through a required graduate level course (ATM 505 Introduction to Atmospheric Physics II) that the PI has been co-teaching. We have also developed online nucleation calculators for H2SO4–H2O binary homogenous nucleation (BHN), H2SO4–H2O–NH3 ternary homogeneous nucleation (THN), H2SO4–H2O-ion binary ion-mediated nucleation (BIMN), and H2SO4–H2O–NH3-ion ternary ion-mediated nucleation (TIMN), which are available to the public and for classroom usage at http://apm.asrc.albany.edu/nrc. We have generated nucleation rate look-up tables for 3-D model applications (Yu et al., 2020b) and made them available to the community via the zenodo data repository http://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3483797. With a machine learning/artificial intelligence (ML/AI) tool, we have also developed a computationally efficient algorithm to accurately predict particle number concentrations and CCN in global climate models. The results of this study were disseminated through over 15 peer-reviewed publications and a number of presentations at national and international conferences.

 

Selected publications resulted from this project:

Jia, H., X. Ma, F. Yu, and J. Quaas, Nature Communications, in press, 2021.

Jia, H., et al., Geophys. Res. Lett., 46, 13,517-13,525, 2019.

Liu, L., F. Yu , L. Du , Z. Yang , J. Francisco, and X. Zhang, PNAS, under revision, 2021.

Mao, J., et al., JGR-Atmospheres, accepted, 2021.

Nair, A., and F. Yu, Atmos. Chem. Phys., 20, 12853-12869, 2020.

Nair, A.A., Yu, F., et al., Geo. Res. Lett., under review, 2021.

Williamson, C. J., et al., Nature, 574, 399-403, 2019.

Yu, F., et al., Atmos. Chem. Phys., 17, 4997-5005, 2017.

Yu, F., et al., Atmos. Chem. Phys.,18, 17451-17474, 2018a.

Yu, F., et al., JGR-Atmospheres, 123, 8315-8325, 2018b.

Yu, F., et al., Atmos. Chem. Phys., 20, 2591-2601, 2020a.

Yu, F., et al., Geosci. Model Dev., 13, 2663-2670, 2020b.
